author: Zach Braziller
title: Seton Hall players ban themselves from social media
text:
“The King of Twitter” and his friends will be logging off come Halloween.
Seton Hall sophomore guard Isaiah Whitehead, who received the nickname from coach Kevin Willard because of his affinity for social media, made the suggestion to his Pirates teammates recently to stay off Twitter, Facebook and the other platforms once the season begins on Oct. 31.
The idea was supported unanimously, in the hopes it would limit some of the distractions Seton Hall felt led to their nosedive last season, when the Pirates lost 12 out of their last 15 games after being ranked as high as No. 19 in the country.
“The one negative can break a team up so easily,” Whitehead said Wednesday morning at Big East Media Day at the Garden. “I think staying off of it will be good. Just trying to focus on the season. … Coach loves it. He thought it was a great idea.”
Whitehead, a Coney Island native and preseason second-team all-league selection, said they have yet to come up with the consequences for breaking the rule. Posting photos on Instagram is allowed.
“For every two good things someone says, there are going to be seven bad things,” Willard said. “After a while, the negativity kinds of beats you down. … It is a distraction at times. It really can get you overwhelmed. My biggest thing with these guys is to keep them to stay focused on how well they can play.
“My biggest problem with these devices, if you watch when they’re on it, it’s 1:00 in the morning. We talk a lot about how much sleep kids needs to get, how much rest you need to get. You can’t rest if your phone is constantly dinging, and their phones are constantly dinging. It’s non-stop. The more they’re off their phones, the more I’m in favor of it.”
